descriptionSet.description: In the centre of the image one can see the Telegraph Office in Kolkata with its high tower. In front of it is a nearly empty street that is lined with trees. A horse carriage can be seen on the street.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: C41.
text-en: Calcutta. Telegraph Office

description-en: In the centre of the image one can see the Telegraph Office in Kolkata with its high tower. In front of it is a nearly empty street that is lined with trees. A horse carriage can be seen on the street. (gs/sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Telegraph Office in Kolkata symbolizes a well-defined and valorized vision of colonial modernity. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Seeing this image, one would associate it with a western metropolitan context rather than rather than with Kolkata. (gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" (gs)
related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-19. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: This postcard was most probably sent from Kotah (Rajasthan) to Kasauli (then in Punjab) in September 1914. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714.
